sentences: Michael Owusu Addo (born July 10, 1988) known professionally as Sarkodie (), is a Ghanaian rapper, songwriter and entrepreneur from Tema.
section: N/A

sentences: His contributions to the Ghanaian music industry have earned him numerous accolades, including the Vodafone Ghana Music Award for "Artiste of the Decade".
section: N/A

sentences: He was announced the first winner of BET's Best International Flow artist at the 2019 BET Hip Hop Awards.
section: N/A

sentences: He is also considered one of the major proponents of the Azonto genre and dance and one of the most successful African rappers of all time.
section: N/A
== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Early life and career beginnings ===
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Sarkodie, the fourth of five children was born on July 10, 1988.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: He was raised in Koforidua before his parents moved to Tema where he started schooling.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: He attended Tema Methodist Day
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Senior High School and proceeded to IPMC, where he earned a degree in graphic design.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Sarkodie began his music career as an underground rapper, participating in Adom FM's popular rap competition Kasahare Level.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: He met his former manager Duncan Williams of Duncwills Entertainment while participating in the aforementioned competition.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: He also met musicians Edem and Castro, who introduced him to Hammer of The Last Two, an established record producer.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Impressed by his rap flows, Hammer allowed Sarkodie to record two tracks for Edems maiden album Volta Regime.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and career beginnings ===
== Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===
== Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: Makye and Rapperholic
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===
== Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: Following his collaboration with Hammer, Sarkodie recorded his debut album Makye.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: Its production was primarily handled by Killbeatz and Jayso.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: The album features guest appearances from Kwaw Kese, J-Town, Sway and Paedae of R2Bees.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: Makye received positive reviews from critics and fans.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: It was supported by a concert held at Holy City Gardens in Accra.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: On 16 September 2009, Sarkodie performed alongside Busta Rhymes at the Busta Rhymes Live in Ghana concert.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: In 2010, his "Push" and "Baby" songs were ranked ninth and thirteenth on Joy FM's Top 50 songs of 2009, respectively.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: The album's lead single "Baby" which features Mugeez of R2bees became an instant hit and gave Sarkodie exposure.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: Sarkodie's second studio album Rapperholic was released in 2012.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: It features guest appearances from Efya, Chidynma, Mugeez of R2Bees, Obrafour, Jayso and EL.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: The album was supported by five singles: "Good Bye", "One Time For Your Mind", "You Go Kill Me", "Living Legend", and "Onyame Nhyira".
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: It received positive reviews from music critics.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: Sarkodie went on a nationwide tour to support the album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: Rapperholic earned Sarkodie his first BET nomination and subsequent win.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: Sarkodie was also featured on the BET Hip Hop Awards cypher alongside Talib Kweli, Jean Grae and Ab-Soul.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: He was the only African act featured on the cypher.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: On 7 July 2012, Sarkodie kicked off his tour of Canada.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: He toured the United States in August 2012, performing in cities and states such as New York City, Ohio, New Jersey, Maryland, Atlanta, Chicago, Texas and Massachusetts.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: After releasing Rapperholic, Sarkodie embarked on a tour to promote the album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: On 27 August 2012, Sarkodie performed alongside R2Bees, Fally Ipupa and Iyanya at the Africa Unplugged Music Festival.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===

sentences: In 2012, Sarkodie performed "How Low" with Ludacris at the 020 Live concert.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2012: Makye and Rapperholic ===
== Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: On October 30, 2013, Sarkodie released the official remix of "You Go Kill Me".
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: The song peaked at number 1 on various charts in Ghana.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: Its remix features vocals from Wizkid, Ice Prince, Navio and EL.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: In January 2014, Sarkodie released his third studio album Sarkology.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: Primarily recorded in Twi, the album features guest appearances from Fuse ODG, Davido, Tiwa Savage, Banky W., Timaya, 2 Face Idibia, Efya, Mugeez, Obrafour, Burna Boy, Vivian Chidid, Vector, Silvastone, Sk Blinks, Stonebwoy, Joey B, J Town, Lil Shaker, Raquel, Sian, Kofi B and AKA.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: Its production was handled by Magnom, Hammer, Killbeatz, Masterkraft and Silvastone, among others.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: The album's launch concert was held at the Accra Sports Stadium in December.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: Sarkodie released the official remix of "Adonai".
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: It features vocals from Castro and appeared on Capital Xtra's list of the Top 35 Afrobeats Songs.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: Sarkodie launched the Sarkcess Music record label in 2014.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: As part of the launch, he premiered the video for "Adonai" (Remix) and "Special Someone".
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: Sarkodie also released the songs "Megye Wo Girl", "Love Rocks", "Chingum", and "Whine Fi Me" under the label.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: On 3 May 2014, Sarkodie performed at the 15th edition of the Ghana Music Awards.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: On 7 June 2014, he joined Miguel on stage to perform the latter's single "How Many Drinks?" at the MTV Africa Music Awards.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: In June 2014, Sarkodie collaborated with Mi Casa, Lola Rae, Davido, Diamond Platnumz and Tiwa Savage to record "Africa Rising", a song for DSTV's campaign of the same name.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: The campaign was designed to inspire Africans to partake in community-based social investment projects.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: The music video for "Africa Rising" was released on June 24, 2014.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===

sentences: It was shot and directed by South African production house Callback Dream.
section: == Life and career == | === 2013–2014: Sarkology, Sarkcess Music and Africa Rising Campaign ===
== Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===
== Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Mary and Highest ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: On 10 June 2015, Sarkodie released the Ace Hood-assisted "New Guy".
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: It was released for digital consumption on 10 June 2015 through Sarkcess Music and Ivy League Records.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Written by the two artists and produced by CedSolo, "New Guy" is an African hip hop and hip hop song that contains alternating rap verses, while its lyrics deal with Sarkodie's desire and motivation for success.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Development for "New Guy" began in early 2015 when Sarkodie paid a total of $25,000 to cover the production fees associated with the recording.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: He also wanted Ace Hood to appear on the track because he considered him "one of the world's most powerful rappers".
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: On 12 September 2015, Sarkodie released Mary, a live album named after his grandmother who died in 2012.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: "Mewu" was released as the lead single from the album two months prior.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: An autograph session for the album was held at the West Hills Mall in Accra.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Sarkodie sold nearly 4,000 copies of the album on the first day of its release.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: In February 2016, he spoke to a group of Harvard Business School students.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Themed "The Art of the Hustle", his speech was primarily about the challenges associated with being an African musician.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Sarkodie also performed at the event following his speech.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Sarkodie held the fourth edition of his Rapperholic concert on Christmas Day.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Tickets for the event sold out within 72 hours of its release.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: The concert featured additional performances from Fuse ODG, R2Bees, Wizkid, Samini, VVIP, Efya and Shatta Wale.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: On 11 March 2016, Sarkodie performed with the music band The Composers at the O2's Indigo venue; the event was hosted by DJ Abrantee.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Sarkodie released his fifth studio album Highest on 8 September 2017.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: It comprises 19 songs, including 3 interludes and a bonus track.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Released through Sarkcess Music and Dice Recordings, the album features guest appearances from Jesse Jagz, Moelogo, Flavour, Korede Bello, Victoria Kimani and Big Narstie.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===

sentences: Highest was primarily produced by Jayso, with additional production from Masterkraft, TSpize, Ced Solo, Nova and Guilty Beatz.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2018: Mary and Highest ===
== Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: Alpha and Black Love =
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===
== Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: Sarkodie released his debut extended play Alpha in June 2019.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: The 6-track EP features guest appearances from Joey B and Ebony Reigns.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: Sarkodie teased his collaboration with Reigns during the Ebony Reigns concert, which commemorated the late singer.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: He released his fifth studio album Black Love on December 20, 2019.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: It features guest artist such as Mr Eazi, Efya, Donae'o, Idris Elba, Stonebwoy, Tekno, Maleek Berry, Herman Suede, King Promise and Kizz Daniel.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: The album was supported by the previously released singles "Party & Bullshit", "Saara", "Do You" and "Can't Let Go".
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: In an interview with OkayAfrica in November, Sarkodie said the album explores themes of black love and relationships.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: On April 19, 2021, Sarkodie announced his soon-to-be-released 7th Studio Album, entitled "No Pressure".
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: A trailer video was uploaded on YouTube, in anticipation of what fans would expect from the album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===

sentences: However, on July 25, 2021, Sarkodie announced a 5 days countdown of the album which would be released on July 30, 2021.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019: Alpha and Black Love ===
== Life and career == | === 2021: No Pressure Album ===
== Life and career == | === 2021: No Pressure Album ===

sentences: No Pressure Album ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2021: No Pressure Album ===

sentences: Sakodie released the album, No Pressure, on 30th July, 2021.
section: == Life and career == | === 2021: No Pressure Album ===

sentences: The album features Wale, Vic Mensa, Giggs, Cassper Nyovest, Harmonize, Oxlade, Kwesi Arthur, Darko Vibes, Medikal, and MOGmusic.
section: == Life and career == | === 2021: No Pressure Album ===
== Recognition ==

sentences: Recognition ==
section: == Recognition ==

sentences: Sarkodie often raps in his native language Twi, a Ghanaian Language and is considered a "multifaceted rapper" due to the various musical styles he possesses.
section: == Recognition ==

sentences: Sarkodie is often named as one of Africa's greatest hip hop artists.
section: == Recognition ==

sentences: MTV Base ranked him sixth on its list of the Hottest African MCs in 2014.
section: == Recognition ==

sentences: In 2013, Lynx TV ranked him first on its list of the "Top 10 Ghanaian Rappers of All Time".
section: == Recognition ==

sentences: In 2015, AfricaRanking.com ranked him third on its list of the "Top 10 African Rappers of 2015".
section: == Recognition ==

sentences: In 2015, The Guardian listed him as one of its top five hip hop acts on the African continent.
section: == Recognition ==

sentences: He was ranked 8th on Forbes and Channel O's 2013 and 2015 list of the Top 10 Richest/Bankable African Artistes.
section: == Recognition ==

sentences: In 2020, he won "Artiste of the Year" during the Ghana Music Awards USA (GMA USA).
section: == Recognition ==
== Philanthropy ==

sentences: Philanthropy ==
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: On July 13, 2013, Sarkodie launched The Sarkodie Foundation, a non-profit organisation dedicated to supporting underprivileged children.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: He made generous donations to the Royal Seed Home Orphanage in Kasoa.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: On December 25, 2014, The Foundation embarked on a feed the kids' campaign in Tema, Ghana, where they provided thousands of kids with bags of rice, yoghurt and beverage cans.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: They also gave away school bags, water bottles, hats and other items.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: Roshi Motman, the CEO of Tigo Telecommunications, was also in attendance to support the campaign.
section: == Philanthropy ==
== Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: Business career and endorsements
section: == Business career and endorsements ==
== Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: Sarkodie owns the Sark by Yas clothing line, which was launched on April 27, 2013.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: The clothing line has accessories for men, women and children.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: In 2012, he was officially unveiled as the Brand Ambassador for Samsung Electronics at the University of Ghana, Legon.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: As part of the event, Samsung unveiled the Samsung Galaxy Pocket and Chief Hero Phones that had customized wallpapers of Sarkodie and his signature; users had the opportunity to download exclusive tracks of Sarkodie.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: He also launched the Obidi Chief headphones and signed an endorsement deal with FanMilk Ghana in 2013.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: Sarkodie is currently in partnership with Tigo Telecommunications Ghana, a brand that sponsored his 2013 Rapperholic tour.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: Sarkodie also has endorsement deals with Standard Chartered Bank - a leading banking firm in Africa as well as Guinness Ghana Limited for their Malt drink product.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: On 30 October 2019, he was appointed as an ambassador for the Year of Return campaign; the honour was conferred on him at the Creative Arts Industry Forum.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: In March 2021, Sarkodie and his little daughter featured in Ghana's leading tooth paste brand - Pepsodent Ghana's #BrushWithMe campaign ad.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: The campaign was done to rally parents and guardians to start and encourage a day and night tooth brushing routine with their children.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==

sentences: This was done to commemorate World oral health day.
section: == Business career and endorsements ==
